newsitem.title: USA: U.S. FDA tightens dioxin testing on catfish.
newsitem.headline: U.S. FDA tightens dioxin testing on catfish.

text.p: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration said Thursday it would change its sampling and testing programme for catfish from Sunday to protect consumers from the risk of dioxin.

The Food and Drug Administration and the U.S. Agriculture Department last week ordered poultry, egg, meat and fish producers handling animals exposed to contaminated feed to make sure dioxin levels were below the federal allowable level of one part per trillion before product sales.
The USDA temporarily closed seven poultry plants and more than 300 other livestock, poultry and egg processing plants because of possible contamination.
The FDA said it will collect and analyse samples of catfish to determine when feed should be halted for catfish to guarantee acceptable levels of dioxin.

"It is not intended to serve as a permanent standard for dioxin in human food, but rather is a reasonable cut-off level for this episode of known, avoidable dioxin contamination of human food from a single source," the agency said in a statement.

The dioxin contamination of animal feed has been traced to a single clay mine in Mississippi, which provided an anti-caking agent for the animal feed. The mine has stopped shipping clay for feed use while the FDA continues to investigate.
